comments.commentBody: "the real issue is how the money is being spent.......Which is exactly the problem. If scientists don't know what the answer is how can you presume to know how well the money is being spent. Basic research is essential. It is hard to set a value on basic research, but the more we know the more ideas we have about how the knowledge can be applied.

"I suggest that the federal government does not need to speed up scientific discovery. There is no need to rush."

Let's discuss this attitude after the next pandemic, big earthquake, devastating mudslides cause by El Nino, or any number of other natural or man-made disasters that cause death and destruction perhaps preventable by scientific discovery.

Let me double down on L's reply. I am a scientist. I spent my entire career working in applied research for a major drug company. I love applied research, but basic research is the life blood of the applied effort. Anyone who thinks that cutting basic research is a good idea is crazy - did you hear that Congress....Crazy.

You're comparing apples and oranges.  Oddsmakers do not pick winners.  They set lines that will equalize the "action" on both sides.  If one side is getting more action, the line moves.  This doesn't really have anything to do with picking winners in the tournament.   By that logic, one should just pick the vegas favorite in every game.  But, as any college hoops fan knows, picking all favorites will get you nowhere - in the regular season or the tournament.  Have you seen how many big favorites have not only failed to cover, but also lost the game straight up - in just the past week?

These are rank amateurs when it comes to picking winners. The odds makers in Vegas have it down to a finite science and I am always amazed how very often the outcomes are near the lines they set.

If one is a "player", he can sense when the unexpected becomes the expected.
For instance, if a team should be an overwhelming favorite but the line doesn't reflect that outcome, one should avoid the favorite like the plague. Case in point: Villanova Wildcats.

When it comes to picking winners, I would rather be a fly on the wall in a Las Vegas odds maker's office then have Chartier's algorithms.

I went to a wedding in Santa Monica two weeks ago, It was mostly people in their 20s and 30s who were in the party. Most of the parents, aunts and uncles are medium conservative, but the young'uns were a lot more liberal, and fun to be around.

They do not relate to stick in the muds like Douthat. The grooms mother and her family is from Virginia, his uncles have a very successful family business, they do not like Obama. His father was raised in California but they live in upstate New York, and are also conservative, so they were in the land of Sodom. The bride's parents are from Michigan, did not get to talk to them much. The couple are professionals, and have adopted the ways of the Santa Monica and Malibu, where conservatism does not fare well.

It is much more fun to be with them, than the repressed parent generation, but then, I was a North Beach person in the 50s and 60s, and can relate to them. They have energy and look forward to a less stifling world than Douthat wants to see. It gives me hope that the GOP fossils and troglodytes that want to take the country back to the 18th century will not prevail in the long run.

Go kids, keep the world a happy place, marry whom you want, keep religion at bay, have joint once in awhile, and do not let the likes of Douthat question your patriotism, his is superficial.

Let me point out to you Douthat, that one of your muses Ayn Rand, was a promoter of individualism. That was the thesis of "The Fountainhead," she believed it is the individual who is the engine of society and innovation.

There is a great line in the Fountainhead where Ellsworth Toohey, the social critic asks Howard Rourke, "What do you think of me." Toohey has been critical of Rourke and is widely read. Rourke's retort is "I don't think of you."

I love this line as I have had occasion to use it over the years. Not the exact words, but when someone has said, "You know what I think of you?" I have answered "Who gives a damn what you think of me?" I also have had the occasion to say it the original way, and the look of astonishment is cause for great mirth.

So Douthat, we who sat around drank wine, listened to poetry, inhaled some fumes, and discussed philosophy in the 50s and 60s, faced the same old criticisms that you dig up from your repressed psyche, and it is just as stale now as it was then.

"Democracy and unionization brought us from the nineteenth-century eighty-hour work week for subsistence wages to a forty hour work week and a "middle class" life for the old working class."
Wrong. The US's manufacturing dominance is what brought us the Post War Boom and its middle class lifestyle everyone seems to long for. There was demand for unskilled and semi-skilled labor in the manufacturing sector. That period ended in October, 1973. The growth of wealth in the middle class began decreasing then.

Many liberals and progressives at the time of the post war boom complained the US standard of living was gained at a cost to the rest of the world. The US was called a neocolonialist and imperialistic empire. The US was supposedly exploiting the Third World for its natural resources. Cheap energy pretty much unencumbered by environmental concerns also drove the economic powerhouse.
Now progressives and liberals are looking up on those years as the Golden Age and are wishing for that prosperity to return. Right, I like Ike.

We do owe a lot to President Clinton though. He signed NAFTA, the repeal of Glass-Steagall and normalized trade relations with China. These actions have also contributed much to to put the US in the economic position it is today.
BTW, WJC also signed the Budapest Memorandum...
